Award.AwardTitle: Pathways: GrACE: A Procedurally Generated Puzzle Game to Stimulate Mindful and Collaborative Informal Learning to Transform Computer Science Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Northeastern University will design, test, and study GrACE, a procedurally generated puzzle game for teaching computer science to middle school students, in partnership with the Northeastern Center for STEM Education and the South End Technology Center. The Principal Investigators will study the effect of computer generated games on students' development of algorithmic and computational thinking skills and their change of perception about computer science through the game's gender-inclusive, minds-on, and collaborative learning environment. The teaching method has potential to significantly advance the state of the art in both game-based learning design and yield insights for gender-inclusive teaching and learning that could have broad impact on advancing the field of computer science education.

Development and evaluation of GrACE will consist of two, year-long research phases, each with its own research question. The first, design and development, phase will focus on how to design a gender-inclusive, educational puzzle game that fosters algorithmic thinking and positive attitude change towards computer science. The content generator will be created using Answer Set Programming, a powerful approach that involves the declarative specification of the design space of the puzzles. The second phase will be an evaluation that studies, by means of a mixed-methods experimental design, the effectiveness of incorporating procedural content generation into an educational game, and specifically whether such a game strategy stimulates and improves minds-on, collaborative learning. Additionally, the project will explore two core issues in developing multiplayer, collaborative educational games targeted at middle school students: what typical face-to-face interactions foster collaborative learning, and what gender differences exist in how students play and learn from the game. The project will reach approximately 100 students in the Boston area, with long-term goals of reaching students worldwide, once the game has been tested with a local audience. Results of the project will yield a new educational puzzle game that can teach algorithmic thinking and effect attitude change regarding computer science. Through the process of creating a gender-inclusive game to teach computer science, it will provide guidelines for future educational game projects. Beyond these individual project deliverables, it will improve our understanding of the potential for procedural content generation to transform education, through its development of a new technique for generating game content based on supplying educational objectives.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we investigated how middle school students can learn about fundamental computer science concepts through playing games. We developed GrACE, a game that requires students to discover an algorithm in order to solve a series of progressively more challenging puzzles. The algorithm players discover through play is Prim?s Algorithm for finding the Minimum Spanning Tree of a graph; this is a commonly taught and used algorithm in computer science, and represents significantly more advanced algorithmic thinking on the part of students than what is typically covered in middle and high school. The game provides students with the ability to automatically generate new levels to practice with, and uses AI to reduce reliance on human-authored game content.

Over the course of this project, we developed several prototypes before we settled on our main concept. For this main concept we developed two versions.The first is a single-player game in which players must help a rabbit find vegetables by choosing the optimum path for the rabbit to dig. This game was played by students in both the United States and Nigeria, as part of STEM outreach programs for youth. The second version built on the strengths of the previous version in terms of its theming and general problem solving, but turned it into a multiplayer game with players taking on different roles in order to solve the puzzle. This version was again tested in Nigeria, and with smaller populations in the US, providing close guidance in libraries and after school programs in order to get deeper insight into how the target audience experienced and played the game.

Major outcomes of the project include:

  1. A review of the design considerations for computer science learning games, through analysis of contemporary games and toys that teach programming. Among several common patterns discovered for these games, we found that game and toy designers often use the metaphor of robots to convey that a game is about ?computer science?, and typically create either single player or highly competitive experiences. With GrACE we sought to subvert these stereotypes of computing through designing a friendly, cooperative game themed around nature.

  2. A deepened understanding of how to design and evaluate computer science learning games in which the player enacts an algorithm rather than directly engages in computer programming (whether real or simulated). GrACE aims to teach about computational thinking, not programming.

  3. A new method for analyzing learning progressions in educational puzzle games. This method involves the creation of AI players, referred to as StrataBots, that can automatically determine what kinds of strategies are needed to succeed on any given level. We can then compare student performance on those levels to bot performance, and use the results to analyze both the efficiency of the designed learning progression and the behavior of the student.

  4. Results that show that students can be engaged by an educational game and learn from it. Students expressed an interest to take the game home and play this with friends. However, while certain students were able to articulate the algorithm, many students were not. Deeper and closer engagement with the target audience revealed that students had trouble understanding the game and needed guidance. This suggests that future work should consider both finding ways for students to reflect on their actions while playing and how to utilize the StrataBots to provide students with (a) puzzles that match their learning trajectory and (b) explicit guidance when they need it.

  5. A comparison between students in Nigeria and the USA that revealed a stark contrast in learning. Algorithmic understanding and game progression was much less with the Nigerian students. These outcomes further stress the need for individualization of learning, but also the realization how far apart students capabilities can be. Educational game designers should be thoroughly aware of this by seeking to playtest and iterate their games with a broader audience.

  6. Insight into the complex set of relationships in designing and evaluating educational games. For example, the collaborative version did foster conversations that we hypothesized would help to articulate what the algorithm is, but they were not always meaningful and came at an expense of individual learning. While some of this warrants further research, preferably at a scale much larger than the current effort, our study results indicate the complexity and the trade-offs inherent with educational games.  

The project?s intellectual merit lay in the novel design of a computer science educational game, the use of procedural content generation to give players space to experiment with different strategies, the development of a new method for analyzing player strategies and learning progressions in educational games, and the comprehensive consideration of various factors (gender, game experience, etc.) and game design variations in understanding learning outcomes. It has had a broader impact through teaching students about computer science in both the US and Nigeria.
